DOCTRINE_BASIC_STRUCTURE.label: Basic Structure
DOCTRINE_BASIC_STRUCTURE.establishing_cases: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973), Minerva Mills v. UOI (1980), I.R. Coelho v. State of TN (2007)
defeaters: Amendment does not alter basic features
DOCTRINE_BASIC_STRUCTURE.key_phrases: "emasculate basic features", "destroy identity of Constitution", "beyond Parliament's constituent power"

DOCTRINE_PROPORTIONALITY_TEST.label: Proportionality Test
DOCTRINE_PROPORTIONALITY_TEST.establishing_cases: Modern Dental College v. State of MP (2016), K.S. Puttaswamy I (2017), K.S. Puttaswamy II/Aadhaar (2018)
DOCTRINE_PROPORTIONALITY_TEST.key_phrases: "legitimate aim", "rational nexus", "least restrictive means", "proportionality stricto sensu"

DOCTRINE_MANIFEST_ARBITRARINESS.label: Manifest Arbitrariness
DOCTRINE_MANIFEST_ARBITRARINESS.establishing_cases: Shayara Bano v. UOI (2017), Navtej Singh Johar v. UOI (2018), Joseph Shine v. UOI (2018)
requires: Non-classification: failure to recognize degrees of harm
defeaters: Rational basis and determining principle present

DOCTRINE_MANEKA_GANDHI_FRAMEWORK_DUE_PRO.label: Maneka Gandhi Framework (Due Process)
DOCTRINE_MANEKA_GANDHI_FRAMEWORK_DUE_PRO.establishing_cases: Maneka Gandhi v. UOI (1978), R.C. Cooper v. UOI (1970)
requires: Procedure must be "right, just and fair"
Procedure must not be "arbitrary, fanciful or oppressive"
Must conform to principles of natural justice
defeaters: Express statutory exclusion of natural justice
Clear legislative intent excluding procedural requirements
DOCTRINE_MANEKA_GANDHI_FRAMEWORK_DUE_PRO.key_phrases: "just, fair and reasonable", "right and just and fair", "not arbitrary, fanciful or oppressive", "Golden Triangle"

DOCTRINE_REASONABLE_CLASSIFICATION_ARTIC.label: Reasonable Classification (Article 14 Twin Test)
DOCTRINE_REASONABLE_CLASSIFICATION_ARTIC.establishing_cases: State of WB v. Anwar Ali Sarkar (1952), Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Tendolkar (1958)
defeaters: No rational nexus to legislative object
DOCTRINE_REASONABLE_CLASSIFICATION_ARTIC.typical_edge_pattern: (Classification) --[twin test]--> (Valid if both satisfied) OR (Violates Art14 if fails)

DOCTRINE_WEDNESBURY_UNREASONABLENESS.label: Wednesbury Unreasonableness
DOCTRINE_WEDNESBURY_UNREASONABLENESS.establishing_cases: Om Kumar v. UOI (2000), Tata Cellular v. UOI (1994)
requires: Decision "so outrageous that no sensible person could have arrived at it"
defeaters: Decision within reasonable range of outcomes
DOCTRINE_WEDNESBURY_UNREASONABLENESS.key_phrases: "so unreasonable that no reasonable authority", "outrageous in defiance of logic", "secondary review"

DOCTRINE_LEGITIMATE_EXPECTATION.label: Legitimate Expectation
DOCTRINE_LEGITIMATE_EXPECTATION.establishing_cases: State of Kerala v. K.G. Madhavan Pillai (1988), Food Corporation v. Kamdhenu (1993)
requires: Express promise or assurance by public authority
DOCTRINE_LEGITIMATE_EXPECTATION.key_phrases: "reasonable expectation", "consistent past practice", "express promise", "fair play in action"

DOCTRINE_NATURAL_JUSTICE_AUDI_ALTERAM_PA.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem
DOCTRINE_NATURAL_JUSTICE_AUDI_ALTERAM_PA.establishing_cases: Maneka Gandhi v. UOI (1978), A.K. Kraipak v. UOI (1969)
defeaters: Conclusion obvious and hearing could not make difference
DOCTRINE_NATURAL_JUSTICE_AUDI_ALTERAM_PA.key_phrases: "no one shall be condemned unheard", "fair opportunity to answer", "speaking order"

DOCTRINE_HARMONIOUS_CONSTRUCTION.label: Harmonious Construction
DOCTRINE_HARMONIOUS_CONSTRUCTION.establishing_cases: CIT v. Hindustan Bulk Carriers (2003) - five principles
DOCTRINE_HARMONIOUS_CONSTRUCTION.requires: [AND - five principles] 1. Avoid head-on clash between provisions 2. Construe provisions harmoniously 3. One provision cannot defeat another unless irreconcilable 4. Give effect to both as much as possible 5. Construction rendering one provision dead is not harmonious
defeaters: Clear legislative intent for one to prevail
DOCTRINE_HARMONIOUS_CONSTRUCTION.key_phrases: "avoid head-on clash", "construe harmoniously", "neither provision rendered otiose"

DOCTRINE_PITH_AND_SUBSTANCE.label: Pith and Substance
DOCTRINE_PITH_AND_SUBSTANCE.establishing_cases: State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsara (1951), Kartar Singh v. State of Punjab (1994)
requires: Challenge to legislative competence based on List entries
Court determines "true nature and character" of legislation
Dominant character must fall within enacting body's list
defeaters: Legislation in pith and substance belongs to another list
Cannot validate legislation if substance clearly outside jurisdiction
DOCTRINE_PITH_AND_SUBSTANCE.typical_edge_pattern: (Legislation) --[pith and substance]--> (Valid if dominant character in correct list)

DOCTRINE_READING_DOWN.label: Reading Down
DOCTRINE_READING_DOWN.establishing_cases: Kedar Nath Singh v. State of Bihar (1962), State of Bombay v. FN Balsara (1951)
requires: Legislative intent not frustrated by narrower reading
DOCTRINE_READING_DOWN.key_phrases: "read down to save constitutionality", "presumption of constitutionality"

CONCEPT_RAPE_DEFINITION.label: Rape Definition
notes: **Age of consent for married woman 15→18 (implements Independent Thought v. UOI)**

CONCEPT_SEXUAL_INTERCOURSE_BY_DECEIT.label: Sexual Intercourse By Deceit
notes: **NEW - false promise of marriage, up to 10 years**

CONCEPT_SNATCHING.label: Snatching
notes: **NEW offense - "suddenly or quickly or forcibly seizes" - up to 3 years**

CONCEPT_SEDITION→SOVEREIGNTY.label: Sedition→Sovereignty
notes: **"Sedition" replaced with "Acts endangering sovereignty, unity and integrity." Subject: "Government"→"India." Punishment: 3yr→7yr + mandatory fine. Scope expanded: includes secession, armed rebellion, subversive activities.**

CONCEPT_ARREST_WITHOUT_WARRANT.label: Arrest Without Warrant
notes: **35(7): No arrest without SP-level approval for elderly (60+) or infirm for offences <3 years**

CONCEPT_FIR.label: Fir
notes: **Electronic filing explicit; Zero FIR statutory recognition; 173(3): preliminary inquiry for 3-7yr offences with DSP approval**

CONCEPT_UNDERTRIAL_DETENTION.label: Undertrial Detention
notes: **First-time offender: bail after 1/3 of maximum sentence; 481(2): multiple pending cases = ineligible**

CONCEPT_ANTICIPATORY_BAIL.label: Anticipatory Bail
notes: **438(1A)/(1B) OMITTED; 482(4): No anticipatory bail for rape of woman under 18 (was 16)**

CONCEPT_EXPERT_OPINION.label: Expert Opinion
notes: **"Any other field" added; Examiner of Electronic Evidence (IT Act) recognized**

CONCEPT_ELECTRONIC_EVIDENCE.label: Electronic Evidence
notes: **MAJOR: "Communication device" explicit; MANDATORY certificate in prescribed format; HASH value required; signed by person in charge AND expert**

signals: this makes it necessary to analyse
doctrine_invocation.example: "This makes it necessary to analyse the origins of privacy and to trace its evolution" - K.S. Puttaswamy (2017)

signals: is a fundamental right which can be traced to
constitutional_nexus.example: "right to privacy is a part of fundamental rights which can be traced to Articles 14, 19 and 21" - K.S. Puttaswamy (2017)

signals: does not answer the test of
requirement_failure.example: "Section 66A cannot possibly be said to create an offence which falls within the expression 'decency' or 'morality'" - Shreya Singhal (2015)

signals: each of the ingredients must be satisfied
conjunctive_satisfaction (AND logic).example: "three-fold criteria of legality, legitimacy of aims, and proportionality" - K.S. Puttaswamy (2017)

signals: We are of the considered view that
We are therefore of the view that
For the foregoing reasons, we hold
We have no hesitation in holding
primary_holding.example: "we hold that bail covers both-release on one's own bond, with or without sureties" - Moti Ram v. State of M.P. (1978)

signals: the principle upon which the case is decided
the ratio decidendi of this case
the law declared by this Court
forms the basis of the decision
ratio_decidendi_marker.example: "The only thing binding in a judge's decision is the principle upon which the case is decided" - Union of India v. Dhanwanti Devi

signals: we need not express any opinion
obiter_dicta_marker.example: "obiter dictum is a mere observation or remark made by the Court, by way of aid, while deciding the actual issue" - Arun Kumar Agrawal v. State of MP

signals: of sufficient importance to warrant overriding
suitable means of furthering this goal
necessary in that there are no alternative measures
proportionality_structuring.example: "a four-fold test: (a) legitimate goal stage, (b) suitability or rational connection stage, (c) necessity stage, (d) balancing stage" - K.S. Puttaswamy/Aadhaar (2018)

signals: insofar as the requirement of...is concerned
having dealt with...we now turn to
does not stand the scrutiny of
For the sake of argument, even if
Even taking the case at its highest
We respectfully agree with the view taken in
The law laid down by this Court in
This view has been followed and reiterated by
The decision is binding on this Court
Judicial discipline obliges them to follow it
The principle laid down in [case] governs the present case
following_precedent.example: "judicial discipline obliges them to follow it, regardless of their doubts about its correctness" - Central Board of Dawoodi Bohra Community (2005)

signals: The facts in the present case are distinguishable
The said decision is not applicable in the present case because
That case was concerned with [X], whereas the present case involves [Y]
The ratio of that decision has no application to the facts of this case
The said ruling is not squarely applicable
distinguishing_precedent.example: "The facts of the present case is clearly distinguishable from the facts of the case dealt with by the Hon'ble Supreme Court" - A.Radhika vs Wilson Sundararaj

signals: We have reservations about the correctness of
We express our doubt about the view taken in
We are not inclined to follow
With great respect, we are unable to agree with
The matter may be placed for hearing before a Bench consisting of a quorum larger
We direct that the matter be referred to a larger Bench
The law laid down in... is no longer good law
We depart from the previous decision
The decision in [case] cannot be treated as good law
The law stated in... is hereby overruled
overruling_precedent.example: "There is nothing in our Constitution which prevents us from departing from a previous decision if we are convinced of its error" - Bengal Immunity Co. v. State of Bihar (1955)

signals: The true ratio of that decision is
That case must be understood as
The ratio decidendi of the judgment is
What the Court meant to say in that case was
The decision is only an authority for what it actually decides
A decision is an authority for what it decides and not what can logically be deduced therefrom
The law laid down by this Court in a decision delivered by a Bench of larger strength is binding on any subsequent Bench of lesser or coequal strength
A Bench of lesser quorum cannot disagree
The decision of a Constitution Bench binds
The Bench strength is determinative of the binding nature
The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India
Article 141 which lays down that the law declared by this Court shall be binding
The decision has only persuasive value
None of these decisions are binding upon Supreme Court but they are authorities of high persuasive value
Foreign judgments and obiter dicta are not binding
This can be accepted as a persuasive precedent
A persuasive precedent is one which the judges are under no obligation to follow
A decision should be treated as given per incuriam when it is given in ignorance of the terms of a statute
A decision rendered by ignorance of a previous binding decision
Such a decision would not be binding as a judicial precedent
A decision passes sub silentio, in the technical sense, when the particular point of law involved in the decision is not perceived by the court
Precedents sub silentio are not regarded as authoritative
A decision which is not express and is not founded on reasons
We shall deal with this contention later
We shall revert to this aspect
This issue shall be addressed presently
We shall advert to this aspect subsequently
deferred_application.example: "As we shall presently see, there is nothing said in either case from which it may be possible to hold that the law laid down... is 'no longer good law'" - Supreme Court Bar Association v. UOI (1998)
deferred_application.resolution_logic: Search FORWARD for resumption markers ("Reverting to...", "Coming now to...", "We now address...") or topic-matching paragraphs
deferred_application.graph_implication: Creates DEFERRED_EDGE; marks node with "awaits_resolution" property

noted_above.resolution_logic: Search BACKWARD for paragraphs containing explicit legal holdings, factual findings, or referenced precedent; semantic similarity + entity matching
noted_above.graph_implication: Creates BACK_REFERENCE edge; current reasoning DEPENDS on earlier established facts/law

aforesaid_facts.resolution_logic: Resolve to Facts section or most recent factual narrative; "aforesaid" = immediately preceding material
aforesaid_facts.graph_implication: Creates FACTUAL_DEPENDENCY edge; holdings CONDITIONAL on factual findings

signals: Having held that... the question of... assumes importance
Once it is established that... the consequence is
Having so held... we proceed to consider
sequential_doctrine.example: "Having held that Article 21 is violated, the question of proportionality assumes importance"
sequential_doctrine.resolution_logic: Doctrine A → Doctrine B dependency; track "having held" to identify primary doctrine
sequential_doctrine.graph_implication: Creates DOCTRINAL_CHAIN edge (transitive support); CRITICAL - if Doctrine A fails, chain collapses

signals: The trinity exists between Article 14, Article 19 and Article 21
golden_triangle_interconnection.example: "A seven-Judge Bench held that a trinity exists between Article 14, Article 19 and Article 21. All these articles have to be read together" - Maneka Gandhi
golden_triangle_interconnection.resolution_logic: Multiple provisions form interconnected doctrine; violation of one triggers all
golden_triangle_interconnection.graph_implication: Creates CONJUNCTIVE_DEPENDENCY edges; mutually reinforcing doctrinal base

signals: Even if we were to accept
hypothetical_concession.example: "Even assuming the petitioner's contention to be correct, the relief cannot be granted for procedural reasons"
hypothetical_concession.resolution_logic: Rhetorical concession; judge provisionally accepts premise but shows conclusion fails anyway
hypothetical_concession.graph_implication: Creates HYPOTHETICAL_CONCESSION edge; ALTERNATIVE_REASONING - holding STRENGTHENED not dependent on this path

signals: Had the authority granted a hearing
If the procedure had been followed
Had the notice been properly served
Were it not for the procedural irregularity
but_for_causation.example: "Had this last opportunity to produce the accused been afforded, the order was legal and valid" - Narata Ram v. State of H.P.
but_for_causation.resolution_logic: Identifies causal factor - if X happened differently, outcome Y would follow; indicates what was DETERMINATIVE
but_for_causation.graph_implication: Creates DETERMINATIVE_FACTOR edge; CRITICAL causal link

signals: The position would have been different if
distinguishing_counterfactual.resolution_logic: Judge identifies why cited precedent doesn't apply; track precedent + factual difference + why material
distinguishing_counterfactual.graph_implication: Creates DISTINGUISHING_EDGE; marks precedent as INAPPLICABLE with reason_node attached

signals: This by itself is fatal to
single_factor_determinism.example: "Therefore, it is on this ground alone the impugned order deserves to be set aside" - Prapbakaran (2010)
single_factor_determinism.resolution_logic: ONE factor is SUFFICIENT for outcome; remaining factors are surplus
single_factor_determinism.graph_implication: Creates DETERMINATIVE edge marked as SUFFICIENT; other edges marked as SURPLUS_TO_REQUIREMENTS - **HIGH VALUE for identifying CRITICAL edges**

signals: Any one of these grounds suffices
Each of these is independently sufficient
sufficient_conditions_disjunctive.resolution_logic: Multiple independent grounds - holding survives if ANY one stands
sufficient_conditions_disjunctive.graph_implication: Creates DISJUNCTIVE_SUPPORT structure; OR-connected edges where holding survives if any single edge valid

sufficient_conditions_conjunctive.resolution_logic: Multiple factors together create sufficient grounds - no single factor sufficient alone
sufficient_conditions_conjunctive.graph_implication: Creates CONJUNCTIVE_SUPPORT structure; AND-connected edges where ALL must hold

rows.changes: **Age of consent for married woman 15→18 (implements Independent Thought v. UOI)**
**NEW - false promise of marriage, up to 10 years**
**NEW offense - "suddenly or quickly or forcibly seizes" - up to 3 years**

**"Sedition" replaced with "Acts endangering sovereignty, unity and integrity." Subject: "Government"→"India." Punishment: 3yr→7yr + mandatory fine. Scope expanded: includes secession, armed rebellion, subversive activities.**
**35(7): No arrest without SP-level approval for elderly (60+) or infirm for offences <3 years**
**Electronic filing explicit; Zero FIR statutory recognition; 173(3): preliminary inquiry for 3-7yr offences with DSP approval**
**First-time offender: bail after 1/3 of maximum sentence; 481(2): multiple pending cases = ineligible**
**438(1A)/(1B) OMITTED; 482(4): No anticipatory bail for rape of woman under 18 (was 16)**
**"Any other field" added; Examiner of Electronic Evidence (IT Act) recognized**
**MAJOR: "Communication device" explicit; MANDATORY certificate in prescribed format; HASH value required; signed by person in charge AND expert**
